psychinterpreter: Getting Started

A Basic Usage Example with Big Five Personality Data

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-02

Source: vignettes/articles/01-Basic_Usage.qmd

Overview

This document demonstrates the functionality of the psychinterpreter package using the Big Five personality data from the psych package. The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a widely-used personality assessment that measures five major dimensions of personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

We’ll test all major features of psychinterpreter including:

  • Basic factor analysis interpretation
  • Persistent chat sessions for efficient LLM usage
  • Export functionality across multiple formats
  • Advanced interpretation features

Setup and Data Preparation 

packages <- c(
  "psychinterpreter",
  "ellmer",
  "psych",
  "lavaan",
  "mirt",
  "dplyr",
  "here",
  "pander"
)
# Load required packages using pacman
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")
Loading required package: pacman
pacman::p_load(char = packages)

# Load the BFI dataset and dictionary
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

Preparing the BFI Data

Exclude demographic variables for factor analysis

bfi <- bfi[,1:25]
bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]

Show the first few rows of the BFI data:

head(bfi,10)

Display the BFI dictionary showing item descriptions:

bfi.dictionary |> select(Item) |> as.data.frame()

Factor Analysis

Determining Number of Factors 

# Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors
pa_result <- fa.parallel(
  bfi,
  fa = "fa",
  n.iter = 100,
  use = "pairwise.complete.obs",
  main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data"
)
Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA

Exploratory Factor Analysis Using 6 Factors

Perform FA with 6 factors identified by the parallel analysis

fa_result <- fa(
  bfi,
  nfactors = pa_result$nfact,
  rotate = "oblimin",
  fm = "ml"
)
summary(fa_result)

Factor analysis with Call: fa(r = bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotate = "oblimin", fm = "ml")

Test of the hypothesis that 6 factors are sufficient.
The degrees of freedom for the model is 165  and the objective function was  0.36
The number of observations was  2800  with Chi Square =  1013.79  with prob <  4.6e-122

The root mean square of the residuals (RMSA) is  0.02
The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.03

Tucker Lewis Index of factoring reliability =  0.922
RMSEA index =  0.043  and the 90 % confidence intervals are  0.04 0.045
BIC =  -295.88
 With factor correlations of
      ML2   ML1   ML3   ML5   ML4   ML6
ML2  1.00  0.25 -0.18 -0.10  0.02  0.18
ML1  0.25  1.00 -0.22 -0.31 -0.19 -0.06
ML3 -0.18 -0.22  1.00  0.19  0.19 -0.03
ML5 -0.10 -0.31  0.19  1.00  0.25  0.14
ML4  0.02 -0.19  0.19  0.25  1.00  0.02
ML6  0.18 -0.06 -0.03  0.14  0.02  1.00
# Extract loading matrix for interpretation
loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame()
round(loadings_matrix, 2)
# Extract factor correlation matrix
factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame()
round(factor_cor_mat, 2)

Chat Setup

Set up persistent chat session

chat <- chat_fa(
  provider = "ollama",
  model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  # set temperature and seed for reproducibility
  params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42)
)

print(chat)
Factor Analysis Chat Session
Provider: "ollama"
Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"
Created: 2025-11-02 17:16:05.690051
Interpretations run: 0

Interpreting Factor Analysis Results

Create variable information dataframe from BFI dictionary

variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),
  description = bfi.dictionary$Item,
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info, 10)

We now generate factor interpretations using the specified LLM:

result <- interpret_fa(
    loadings = loadings_matrix,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  n_emergency = 2,
  additional_info = NULL,
  factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,
  sort_loadings = TRUE,
  word_limit = 100,
  max_line_length = 80,
  silent = FALSE,
  echo = "none",
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 2,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  chat_session = chat
)
ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character
ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"

    ML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

    ML5 = .25, ML6 = .02
  • ML6: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -.06, ML3 = -.03,
    ML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

Detailed Factor Interpretations

Factor 1 (ML2):: Negative Affectivity

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 9.22% nFactor Correlations: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -.18, ML5 = -.10,

ML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

nnVariables:nn 1. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851) 2. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851) 3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .639) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .402) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Weak, .389)

LLM Interpretation:
Negative Affectivity This factor is dominated by the five neuroticism items (N1–N5), all of which tap into negative emotionality—anger, irritation, mood swings, sadness, and panic. The high loadings (0.39–0.85) confirm strong convergent validity: the items cohere around a single affective dimension. Discriminant validity is supported by relatively low correlations with the other factors (e.g., –0.18 with Conscientiousness, –0.10 with Agreeableness), indicating that negative affect is distinct from orderliness, empathy, and openness. The modest positive link to Social Withdrawal (.25) reflects that those who experience frequent negative emotions tend to withdraw socially, but the factor remains a separate construct.

Factor 2 (ML1):: Social Withdrawal

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.9% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -.22, ML5 = -.31,

ML4 = -.19, ML6 = -.06

nnVariables:nn 1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .686) 2. E1, Don’t talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .587) 3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.550) 4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .436) 5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -.405) 6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .355) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.349)

LLM Interpretation:
Social Withdrawal This factor is defined by the extraversion items E1–E5, but with a distinctive pattern: E1 (“don’t talk a lot”) and E2 (“find it difficult to approach others”) load positively, whereas E3 (“know how to captivate people”), E4 (“make friends easily”), and E5 (“take charge”) load negatively. This pattern signals a single dimension of introversion—high scores indicate social reticence, low scores indicate sociability. Convergent validity is evident in the strong loadings (0.59–0.69). Discriminant validity is supported by modest correlations with other factors (e.g., .25 with Negative Affectivity, .18 with Social‑Intellectual Integration) and negligible links to Conscientiousness and Openness, underscoring its distinctness.

Factor 3 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 7.71% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -.18, ML1 = -.22, ML5 = .19,

ML4 = .19, ML6 = -.03

nnVariables:nn 1. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .680) 2. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.634) 3. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .551) 4. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .547) 5. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.541)

LLM Interpretation:
Conscientiousness interpretation This factor is anchored by the five conscientiousness items C1–C5, all of which reflect orderliness, perfectionism, and planning. The loadings (0.55–0.68) are high and uniformly positive, confirming strong convergent validity. The factor is distinct from Agreeableness and Extraversion, as evidenced by negative correlations with Social Withdrawal (–0.22) and Agreeableness (–0.31). Its modest positive link to Openness (.19) suggests that highly organized individuals may also value intellectual exploration, yet the core construct remains a separate dimension of self‑regulation and diligence in daily life.

Factor 4 (ML5):: Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 6.79% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -.10, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .19,

ML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

nnVariables:nn 1. A2, Inquire about others’ well-being. (Positive, Strong, .688) 2. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .617) 3. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Strong, -.560) 4. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Moderate, .451) 5. A4, Love children. (Positive, Weak, .391)

LLM Interpretation:
Agreeableness interpretation The factor is defined by the five agreeableness items A1–A5, which capture empathy, caring, and prosocial orientation. The loadings range from –0.56 (indifference) to 0.69 (inquiry), yielding a clear convergent pattern: high scores reflect warmth and cooperation, low scores reflect callousness. Discriminant validity is evident in the negative correlation with Social Withdrawal (–0.31) and the positive link to Openness (.25), indicating that agreeable individuals are socially engaged and intellectually curious, yet the factor remains distinct from the other personality dimensions.

Factor 5 (ML4):: Openness

Number of significant loadings: 6 nVariance explained: 6.27% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -.19, ML3 = .19,

ML5 = .25, ML6 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .656) 2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .564) 3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Moderate, -.451) 4. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .392) 5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .376) 6. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Weak, -.367)

LLM Interpretation:
Openness interpretation This factor is driven by the five openness items O1–O5, which collectively assess imaginative thinking, intellectual curiosity, and willingness to explore new ideas. The loadings (0.56–0.66) are strong and positive for O1, O3, and O4, while O2 and O5 load negatively, reflecting a preference for novelty versus avoidance of complexity. Convergent validity is clear, and discriminant validity is supported by the factor’s modest positive correlation with Agreeableness (.25) and Conscientiousness (.19), yet it remains distinct from the other personality dimensions.

Factor 6 (ML6):: Social‑Intellectual Integration

Number of significant loadings: 2 nVariance explained: 3.12% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -.06, ML3 = -.03,

ML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Positive, Moderate, .403) 2. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Positive, Weak, .353)

LLM Interpretation:
Social‑Intellectual Integration interpretation This factor captures a moderate blend of social engagement (E4, E3), intellectual curiosity (O2, O5), and conscientiousness (C4), along with agreeableness (A5, A4) and mild neuroticism (N5, N4). The loadings are modest (0.20–0.40), indicating a cross‑cutting construct that does not align tightly with any single personality domain. Convergent validity is suggested by the consistent pattern of social‑intellectual traits, while discriminant validity is upheld by low correlations with the other factors (e.g., .14 with Agreeableness, .18 with Negative Affectivity), underscoring its distinctness.

Cross-Loading Variables

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):

  • E3: Know how to captivate people.: ML1 (-.349), ML4 (.392)
  • N4: Often feel blue.: ML2 (.389), ML1 (.436)
  • O2: Avoid difficult reading material.: ML4 (-.367), ML6 (.353)
  • O4: Spend time reflecting on things.: ML1 (.355), ML4 (.376)
  • O5: Will not probe deeply into a subject.: ML4 (-.451), ML6 (.403)

Let’s check the global token usage tracked by the chat:

print(chat)

Plot the loading matrix with factor names:

plot(result,
     cutoff = 0.3)

Export Functionality

We can export the results to multiple formats

# TXT export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "txt",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis"))
# MD export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "md",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis"))

Generic Methods for ‘psych’, ‘lavaan’, and ‘mirt’ Objects

psych Package 

interpret(
  fa_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  output_format = "markdown"
)

Social Withdrawal This factor is defined by the extraversion items E1–E5, but with a distinctive pattern: E1 (“don’t talk a lot”) and E2 (“find it difficult to approach others”) load positively, whereas E3 (“know how to captivate people”), E4 (“make friends easily”), and E5 (“take charge”) load negatively. This pattern signals a single dimension of introversion—high scores indicate social reticence, low scores indicate sociability. Convergent validity is evident in the strong loadings (0.59–0.69). Discriminant validity is supported by modest correlations with other factors (e.g., .25 with Negative Affectivity, .18 with Social‑Intellectual Integration) and negligible links to Conscientiousness and Openness, underscoring its distinctness.

Factor 3 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 7.71% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -.18, ML1 = -.22, ML5 = .19,

ML4 = .19, ML6 = -.03

nnVariables:nn 1. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .680) 2. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.634) 3. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .551) 4. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .547) 5. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.541)

LLM Interpretation:
Conscientiousness This factor is anchored by the five conscientiousness items C1–C5, all of which reflect orderliness, perfectionism, and planning. The loadings (0.55–0.68) are high and uniformly positive, confirming strong convergent validity. The factor is distinct from Agreeableness and Extraversion, as evidenced by negative correlations with Social Withdrawal (–0.22) and Agreeableness (–0.31). Its modest positive link to Openness (.19) suggests that highly organized individuals may also value intellectual exploration, yet the core construct remains a separate dimension of self‑regulation and diligence in daily life.

The loadings range from –0.56 (indifference) to 0.69 (inquiry), yielding a clear convergent pattern: high scores reflect warmth and cooperation, low scores reflect callousness. Discriminant validity is evident in the negative correlation with Social Withdrawal (–0.31) and the positive link to Openness (.25), indicating that agreeable individuals are socially engaged and intellectually curious, yet the factor remains distinct from the other personality dimensions.

lavaan Package 

# Specify a CFA model for BFI data
fa_lavaan <- lavaan::efa(bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotation = "oblimin")
# interpret lavaan model
interpret(
  fa_lavaan,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  output_format = "markdown"
)

Also works with lavaa::cfa():

# specify and fit a CFA model
cfa_model <- "
  O =~ O1 + O2 + O3 + O4 + O5
  C =~ C1 + C2 + C3 + C4 + C5
  E =~ E1 + E2 + E3 + E4 + E5
  A =~ A1 + A2 + A3 + A4 + A5
  N =~ N1 + N2 + N3 + N4 + N5
  "
cfa_fit <- lavaan::cfa(cfa_model, data = bfi, std.lv = TRUE)

# interpret lavaan cfa model
interpret(
  cfa_fit,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE
)

LLM Interpretation:
Openness to Experience is defined by strong loadings on O1 (ideas), O3 (higher‑level conversation), and O4 (reflection), with negative loadings on O2 (avoiding difficult reading) and O5 (avoiding deep probing). This pattern confirms convergent validity: the items cluster around intellectual curiosity, imagination, and a willingness to explore abstract concepts. The factor is distinct from Conscientiousness (r=.30), Extraversion (r=–.45), Agreeableness (r=–.30), and Neuroticism (r=–.11), indicating a separate dimension of open‑mindedness and creative thinking.

This pattern demonstrates convergent validity: the items cohere around self‑discipline, orderliness, and goal orientation. The factor is distinct from Openness (r=.30), Extraversion (r=–.36), Agreeableness (r=–.33), and Neuroticism (r=–.28), underscoring a separate construct of reliability and structured behavior.

The loadings reveal a clear convergent pattern: the factor represents social reticence versus sociability. It is distinct from Openness (r=–.45), Conscientiousness (r=–.36), Agreeableness (r=.68), and Neuroticism (r=.24), indicating a separate dimension of outward social energy and assertiveness.

  cutoff = 0.3,
  chat_session = chat,
  word_limit = 100,
  heading_level = 3,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  output_format = "markdown"
)

Openness to Experience is the dominant factor in F1, evidenced by strong positive loadings on O1 (ideas), O3 (higher‑level conversation), and O4 (reflection), and negative loadings on O2 (avoiding difficult reading) and O5 (avoiding deep probing). The inclusion of E3 and E5 suggests that imaginative individuals also captivate and lead. Convergent validity is clear: all items cluster around intellectual curiosity and creative exploration. Correlations with other factors are modest (e.g., r=.25 with Conscientiousness, r=–.45 with Extraversion), supporting discriminant validity and positioning Openness as a distinct, open‑minded construct.

Factor 2 (F2):: Neuroticism

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 11.07% nFactor Correlations: F1 = .00, F3 = -.21, F4 = -.17,

F5 = -.14, F6 = .28

nnVariables:nn 1. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .914) 2. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .906) 3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .690) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .455) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .421)

LLM Interpretation:
Neuroticism dominates F2, with loadings above .90 on N1–N3 and strong loadings on N4 and N5, capturing anger, irritation, mood swings, sadness, and panic. The factor also includes modest loadings on A1, A5, C5, and E5, indicating that high emotional volatility is associated with lower empathy, lower assertiveness, and lower conscientiousness. Convergent validity is evident: all items measure negative affect. Discriminant validity is supported by low correlations with Openness (.27) and Conscientiousness (–.14), while a moderate positive correlation with Social Engagement (.28) reflects that neurotic individuals may seek social support, yet remain a distinct affective construct.

Factor 3 (F3):: Extraversion

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 9.63% nFactor Correlations: F1 = .29, F2 = -.21, F4 = .24,

F5 = .40, F6 = -.05

nnVariables:nn 1. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .764) 2. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Negative, Very Strong, -.715) 3. E1, Don’t talk a lot. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Weak, .365)

LLM Interpretation:
Extraversion is captured in F3, with strong negative loadings on E1 and E2 and positive loadings on E3, E4, and E5, indicating that low talkativeness and social difficulty co‑occur with the ability to captivate, make friends, and take charge. The factor also loads on A5 and A3, suggesting that sociable individuals feel comfortable with others and can provide comfort. Convergent validity is clear: all items reflect outward social energy. Discriminant validity is evident through modest correlations with Neuroticism (–.21) and Conscientiousness (0.24), confirming Extraversion as a distinct, socially oriented construct.

LLM Interpretation:
Conscientiousness dominates F4, with high positive loadings on C1, C2, and C3 and strong negative loadings on C4 and C5, reflecting exacting standards, perfectionism, and planning versus half‑way and time‑wasting behaviors. The factor also includes modest loadings on A4 and E5, indicating that organized individuals value child care and leadership. Convergent validity is evident: all items measure self‑discipline and orderliness. Discriminant validity is supported by low correlations with Openness (.25) and Extraversion (–.17), while a moderate positive correlation with Agreeableness (.25) shows that conscientious people are also cooperative, yet remain a distinct, goal‑oriented construct.

LLM Interpretation:
Agreeableness is defined by F5, with strong positive loadings on A2, A3, A5, and moderate loadings on A1 and A4, capturing inquiry, comfort, ease, indifference, and love for children. The factor also includes modest loadings on C3 and C2, suggesting that agreeable individuals are also somewhat organized. Convergent validity is clear: all items measure warmth and prosociality. Discriminant validity is evident through low correlations with Openness (.27) and Conscientiousness (–.14), while a moderate positive correlation with Extraversion (.40) indicates that agreeable people are also socially engaging, yet remain a distinct, empathic construct.
